https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The identification of global, national, state-wide, or local features of geology (such as igneous, metamorphic, sedimentary, stratigraphic, structural, geochemical, mineralogical, paleontological, geomorphical, pedological, and hydrological attributes) that are: (a) intrinsically important or culturally important sites; (b) offer information or insights into the formation or evolution of the Earth, or into the history of science, or (c) that can be used for research, teaching, or reference. Geoheritage is inextricably linked to geoconservation, for the preservation of these sites for posterity.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value:
Definition adapted from:
Brocx, M and Semeniuk, V 2007, Geoheritage and geoconservation — history, definition, scope and scale: Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia, v. 90, p. 53–87.

Geoheritage is inextricably linked to geoconservation, for the preservation of these sites for posterity.
